intro: Codonopsis convolvulacea subsp. grey-wilsonii, commonly known as the Grey-Wilson's snakeroot, is a flowering plant native to Southeast Asia. It belongs to the Campanulaceae family and is characterized by its tubular, bell-shaped flowers that typically range in color from white to pink. The plant has a creeping rootstock and produces small, herbaceous leaves that are often hairy. It thrives in moist, shaded environments and is often found in forest undergrowth. Due to its ornamental value and medicinal properties, it is occasionally cultivated in horticultural settings.
